questions.text: Does the person you are answering for trip over obstacles or objects on the floor that you did not see?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty walking down stairs, for visual reasons?
Does the person you are answering for trip at the edges of pavements going up?
Does the person you are answering for trip at the edges of pavements going down / or have difficulty stepping off buses or other public transport?
Does the person you are answering for hesitate to go down a hill or a steep slope? (i.e.: have a feeling of 'getting stuck' at the top)
Does the person you are answering for have to look down when crossing floor boundaries? (e.g.: where floor surface meets carpet)
Does the person you are answering for miss food on the near or far side of your plate?
Does the person you are answering for miss food on the right side or left side of your plate?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty finding the beginning of a line when reading a printed book?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty finding the next word in a sentence while reading a printed book?
Has the person you are answering for walked out in front of traffic because you have difficulty judging moving traffic?
Does the person you are answering for bump into doorframes or partly open doors when walking through them?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty seeing the two sides of an open book or filling out two sides of a form?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty seeing the detail or spotting something in the scenery when riding as a passenger in a moving vehicle?

ups.text: Which quickly moving thing(s) does the person you are answering for have difficulty in seeing?  You may select one or more items for this question.

choices: A cursor on a computer screen

questions.text: Does the person you are answering for have difficulty seeing things which are moving quickly? (e.g.: such as small animals / children; moving water as from a flowing tap or in a river, the cursor on a computer screen, passing cars, or a ball in flight).
Does the person you are answering for avoid watching fast moving TV and film images?
Does the person you are answering for prefer to watch slow moving TV and film images?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty catching something that is thrown to them (e.g.: a ball)?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty seeing something that is pointed out in the distance?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty finding a close friend or relative who is standing in a group?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty finding an item they want in a supermarket aisle/lane? (e.g. finding their chosen breakfast cereal amongst many breakfast cereals)
Does the person you are answering for lose their bearing in places where there is a lot to see? (e.g. a crowded shop)
Does the person you are answering for feel lost in places which are well known to them? (e.g.: their neighborhood; workplace; their usual transit hubs)
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty locating an item of clothing in a pile of clothes?
Does the person you are answering for often lose things?
Does the person you are answering for sit close to the television? (e.g. less than about 30cm)
Does the person you are answering for find copying words or drawings to and from a screen or a document, time consuming and difficult?
Does the person you are answering for prefer holding onto something (handrail, walking stick, a person) while walking outside?
Does the person you are answering for find uneven ground difficult to walk over (i.e. grass, a hiking trail)?
Does the person you are answering for bump into low furniture in a room that they know well?
Does the person you are answering for bump into low furniture if it has been moved in the room without their previous knowledge?
Does the person you are answering for get upset if furniture is moved in a room that they are familiar with?
Does the person you are answering for explore floor boundaries with their foot before crossing them? (e.g. floor/carpet edge)

ups.text: Boundaries that are new to them?
Boundaries that are well known to them?

questions.text: Does the person you are answering for find inside floor boundaries difficult to cross?
Does the person you are answering for find any difficulty in reaching for or picking up objects accurately? (e.g.: do they reach beyond or around the object)
When picking up an object, does the person you are answering for grasp it incorrectly? (e.g.: do they miss or knock the object over?)
Does the person you are answering for find it difficult to keep to a challenging task if there are distractions around them?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty getting back to a task after being distracted?
Does the person you are answering for bump into things while moving and having a conversation at the same time?
Does the person you are answering for miss objects when they are different from their background, but seem to 'pop out' and are obvious to others? e.g.: A bright object/football in the grass?
Do rooms with a lot of clutter cause the person you are answering for difficulty?
Does the person you are answering for prefer quiet places/open countryside in comparison to busy cities?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty getting around in a busy place? e.g.: supermarket/busy street/airport?
Does the person you are answering for find it annoying when other restless people cause distraction?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty recognising close relatives in real life?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty recognising close relatives from photographs?
Does the person you are answering for mistakenly identify strangers as people known to them?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty understanding the meaning of facial expressions? (e.g. when someone is smiling or annoyed or sad)
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty naming common colours?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty recognising or naming basic shapes such as squares, triangles and circles?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty recognising familiar objects? (e.g.: the family car)

Does the person you are answering for find it difficult to identify where sound is coming from? (e.g.: in their home, if someone calls from a different room, can they tell from which room by the direction of the voice?)
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty playing team games, especially if there are a lot of players and they are all moving?

Does the person you are answering for have difficulty identifying objects when they are on a similar background such as a white T-shirt on a white sheet? (or black shoes on a black background/in a dark cupboard)

Does the person you are answering for have difficulty reading crowded text on paper or on a computer screen, but can cope better if some of the text is covered or removed, or the spacing is increased?
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty finding the letters on a keyboard?

Does the person you are answering for have difficulty recognising an object if it is partially hidden (or not fully visible), or viewed from an unusual angle? (e.g.; a bicycle hidden partly behind a wall)
Does the person you are answering for have difficulty recognising right and left shoes?

Does the person you are answering for have difficulty recognising people, word, objects if changed in presentation style? i.e. hairstyle; grown a moustache; font of the text; a familiar object presented from a rear view or a top-down view?
